title: Wes Gordon Designed With the Perspective of a Cinematic Gardener for Carolina Herrera Fall 2025
description: For his Fall 2025 collection for Carolina Herrera, creative director Wes Gordon brought the garden from one of his favorite films, "Being There" (1979) to life. Touches of this vision can be felt via oversized satin waistbands featuring blooming rosettes, gold metal tulip brooches pinned to ...Continue reading
author: Brooke Frischer
excerpt: The designer was inspired by the character of Chance the Gardener from the 1979 film "Being There," using plenty of florals to convey his message.
text: HomeFashion WeekThe designer was inspired by the character of Chance the Gardener from the 1979 film "Being There," using plenty of florals to convey his message.Photo: Launchmetrics SpotlightThe designer was inspired by the character of Chance the Gardener from the 1979 film "Being There," using plenty of florals to convey his message.For his Fall 2025 collection for Carolina Herrera, creative director Wes Gordon brought the garden from one of his favorite films, "Being There" (1979) to life. Touches of this vision can be felt via oversized satin waistbands featuring blooming rosettes, gold metal tulip brooches pinned to cashmere sweaters and multi-colored floral jacquard fabrics."There's this beautiful, romantic atmosphere to the film with these gardens and fall and winter," Gordon told Fashionista backstage following the show. "Thinking about a woman taking a brisk walk through Central Park on a fall day — maybe it's just rained and the pavement is a little wet — that inspired the color palette as well, and the character of the woman I was designing for."Throughout the collection, Gordon's use of color varies from typical autumn hues like cherry reds, forest greens and deep plums to more expected spring shades, including airy periwinkles, vivid fuscias and bright whites."I think a color is a color. A color works 12 months of the year," explained Gordon. "I don't believe in banning colors for certain months. If a color is beautiful, it's beautiful any day. And our goal at Herrera is to always capture beauty."Scroll to ContinueRecommended ArticlesA fair share of the collection also features youthful mini and sheer silhouettes, as well as dramatic embroideries of ASMR-worthy pailettes: "I definitely think the woman is stronger, sexier and more confident this season than she's ever been. She has her hair down, she's fresh. There's an attitude there — a real modernity."See the Carolina Herrera Fall 2025 collection below.Carolina Herrera Fall 2025. html:
• Home
  • Fashion Week

The designer was inspired by the character of Chance the Gardener from the 1979 film "Being There," using plenty of florals to convey his message.

Photo: Launchmetrics Spotlight

The designer was inspired by the character of Chance the Gardener from the 1979 film "Being There," using plenty of florals to convey his message.

For his Fall 2025 collection for Carolina Herrera, creative director Wes Gordon brought the garden from one of his favorite films, "Being There" (1979) to life. Touches of this vision can be felt via oversized satin waistbands featuring blooming rosettes, gold metal tulip brooches pinned to cashmere sweaters and multi-colored floral jacquard fabrics.

"There's this beautiful, romantic atmosphere to the film with these gardens and fall and winter," Gordon told Fashionista backstage following the show. "Thinking about a woman taking a brisk walk through Central Park on a fall day — maybe it's just rained and the pavement is a little wet — that inspired the color palette as well, and the character of the woman I was designing for."

Throughout the collection, Gordon's use of color varies from typical autumn hues like cherry reds, forest greens and deep plums to more expected spring shades, including airy periwinkles, vivid fuscias and bright whites.

"I think a color is a color. A color works 12 months of the year," explained Gordon. "I don't believe in banning colors for certain months. If a color is beautiful, it's beautiful any day. And our goal at Herrera is to always capture beauty."

Scroll to Continue

Recommended Articles

A fair share of the collection also features youthful mini and sheer silhouettes, as well as dramatic embroideries of ASMR-worthy pailettes: "I definitely think the woman is stronger, sexier and more confident this season than she's ever been. She has her hair down, she's fresh. There's an attitude there — a real modernity."

See the Carolina Herrera Fall 2025 collection below.
